Comment: As usual - good move - but make sure you have a plan based on e4
equal position with foothold in the centre - but white has the move
development with a threat
development with defense
good developing move, opens up for 0-0
likewise development - note black is still a move behind on the Kside

Probably too aggressive too early. Bxp wins N and p for the B,  I'd prefer you to play a specific opening understanding the moves, their sequence, and their intent. Ask yourself - is this move part of my opening plan ! If not why are you playing this. If it is part of a plan, you need to reconsider that plan, or else force some advantage in the next sequence of moves.
This was thoughtless at best and I apologise. It is bad because 1. I give up a hold in the centre 2. it blocks the B 3. it semi-opens the e file 4. f6 becomes vulnerable to e5
always good to develop with a threat - it cuts down options for a response
best of a bad lot !  If white exploits this advantage the black position will be messed up, and worse, if not defended accurately.
e5 straight away maintains the pressure. "Strike while the iron is hot" "Never look a gift horse in the mouth" or even "Don't give a sucker an even break" spring to mind
I have the time now to defend
Not bad - but I think I did well to swap a dodgey N for a good B.
Not out of the woods yet, but I can see more daylight
I expected e5 again. You really are not exploiting your advantage at all.
B was fine on c4 - you need to develop your other N, and look at the vulnerability of b2 and R on a1
B was fine on c4 - you need to develop your other N, and look at the vulnerability of b2 and R on a1
The B on c5 is not great because it is blocked by d4 - you are opening a vulnerability on b2 and a1, pushing pawns making them weaker, moving Bc5 onto a better square ???

Now your pawns are messed up, structure is weakened, K is exposed, N not developed, c2 is a problem, etc.

You should be looking at Nd2, or Re1, or even c3. In a position like this, think about moves that improve the situation, develop your N, get R on e or g file, connect Rs, resolve the constraint of d4, etc.  I presume you are preparing for e5, but even if you play e5 next after pxp, pxp, you will have an unsupported p on e5, and you don't want to play f4 to support it.  Re1 would be better

Again a pawn move achieving little. You really need to think about N development and activating Rs. When you are not sure what to do, resist pushing pawns !  I know you are hoping for pxp but it is always better to improve your own position than hope your opponent will disimprove theirs.
